title: 115_hr1728
content: Boundary modification for Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area in Idaho. In this section, key definitions include the Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area, Gateway West high-voltage transmission line project, a specific map, sage-grouse species, and the Secretary of the Interior. The Snake River Birds of Prey NCA Boundary Adjustment dated October 13, 2016, defines sage-grouse species as the greater sage-grouse and the Secretary as the Secretary of the Interior. The Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area boundary is modified to include approximately 4726 acres of land depicted as "BLM Administered Lands" on the map. The proposed adjustment includes adding approximately 4726 acres of BLM Administered Lands to the Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area office, excluding 761 acres of Segment 8 Revised Proposed Route. Additionally, 86 acres of BOR Administered Lands are also included in the adjustment. The adjustment adds 4726 acres of BLM Administered Lands to the Conservation Area office, including 86 acres of BOR Administered Lands. It excludes 761 acres of Segment 8 Revised Proposed Route. The Secretary will issue a right-of-way to Gateway West for construction and maintenance of transmission lines in specified lands, including Segment 9 Revised Proposed Route. The Secretary will issue a right-of-way to Gateway West for construction and maintenance of transmission lines in specified lands, aligning with revised proposed routes for segments 8 and 9. Conditions will be included in the right-of-way for activities related to fire prevention and suppression. Gateway West will be granted a right-of-way for construction and maintenance of transmission lines on specified lands, aligning with revised proposed routes for segments 8 and 9. Conditions for mitigation of impacts related to the transmission lines will be in accordance with the Compensatory Mitigation and Enhancement framework. Gateway West will contribute $2,000 per acre of right-of-way in the Conservation Area during construction of Segment 8 and Segment 9 Revised Proposed Route, with a stipulation that Compensatory Mitigation and Enhancement costs shall not exceed $8,543,440.. The Revised Proposed Route, totaling 761 acres for Segment 8 and 1,845 acres for Segment 9, will be designated for conservation purposes, including enhancing National Landscape Conservation System Units in Idaho. Gateway West will cover all costs associated with boundary modifications, surveys, recording, and other reasonable expenses. Standard terms and conditions under the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 will apply. The Secretary will oversee administration. The Secretary will administer the lands as part of the Conservation Area and National Landscape Conservation System. Administrative jurisdiction over 86 acres of land is transferred. The administrative jurisdiction over 86 acres of land is transferred from the Bureau of Reclamation to the Bureau of Land Management. A management plan amendment is required within 18 months to address the long-term management of the lands in the Conservation Area. Management Plan Amendment required within 18 months to address long-term management of lands in the Conservation Area, including determining appropriate activities, continuing livestock grazing with regulations, and allowing motorized access on existing roads. The enactment of this section allows grazing, motorized access on existing roads, and hunting/fishing on specified lands, subject to necessary regulations and laws. The Cotterel Wind Power Project area on approximately 203 acres of Federal land is prohibited from being used for wind electricity production. The Secretary of the Interior will establish a Bureau of Land Management Foundation as a charitable nonprofit corporation to address specific challenges such as reclamation of legacy wells, sustainable management of wild horses, and expanded scientific understanding. The Bureau of Land Management Foundation will support reclamation of legacy wells, contaminated native lands, sustainable management of wild horses, expanded scientific understanding of development techniques, voluntary conservation activities, and identification of cultural and historical treasures on public lands.
